episodeTitle: Angel Island Obliterated! The Horror of the Raigo's Advent
japanesTitle: エンジェル島消滅！雷迎降臨の恐怖！！
romanizedTitle: Angel-tou Shoumetsu! Raigou Kourin no Kyoufu!!
description: Enel unleashes his devastating Raigo technique, completely obliterating Angel Island and leaving only a massive crater in the clouds. As the survivors grieve their destroyed homeland, Luffy declares his determination to ring the golden bell before Enel can claim it.
usReleaseNote: Episodes 168-195 did not air on U.S. television but were released on Funimation DVD

events.title: Robin Reveals the Golden Bell's Location
events.description: Nico Robin tells Wyper that the Golden Bell sits atop Giant Jack, the massive beanstalk. She supports her claim with evidence from Noland's log book, finally revealing the location of the Shandians' sacred treasure that they've searched for over 400 years.
events.significance: This revelation provides the first concrete evidence of the Golden Bell's location, which has been sought by the Shandians for centuries. It bridges the gap between Noland's historical account and the present-day quest, validating both Cricket's faith in his ancestor and the Shandians' ancestral mission.

quotes.text: The Golden Bell sits atop Giant Jack.
quotes.speaker: Nico Robin
quotes.context: Robin reveals the location based on Noland's log book

events.title: Enel Unleashes Raigo - The Descending Thunder
events.description: Enel activates his most devastating technique, Raigo, condensing massive thunderclouds generated by his ark Maxim into an enormous sphere of lightning. This technique serves as his ultimate weapon of mass destruction, designed to annihilate entire islands.
events.significance: The debut of Raigo establishes Enel as one of the most destructive antagonists seen in the series thus far. This technique demonstrates the terrifying potential of Logia-type Devil Fruits when combined with technology, foreshadowing the catastrophic power that will be used against all of Skypiea.

quotes.text: Witness the true power of god! Raigo!
quotes.speaker: Enel

events.title: The Complete Destruction of Angel Island
events.description: Enel's Raigo descends upon Angel Island with the force of an atomic explosion, completely obliterating the city and leaving only a massive crater in the clouds. The entire population's homeland is destroyed in seconds, with countless lives lost and the survivors left in shock and despair.
events.significance: This is one of the darkest moments in One Piece up to this point, showing the series' willingness to depict genuine tragedy and mass casualties. The destruction serves as the ultimate demonstration of Enel's god complex and the stakes of stopping him. The atomic bomb imagery resonates particularly with Japanese audiences given their historical experience.

events.title: Skypieans and Shandians Grieve Together
events.description: In the aftermath of Angel Island's destruction, both Skypieans and Shandians share their grief over the mutual losses they've suffered. This moment of shared tragedy begins to bridge the 400-year divide between the two peoples, showing that both sides have lost loved ones to this senseless conflict.
events.significance: This scene represents a crucial turning point in the centuries-long war between Skypieans and Shandians. Their shared suffering humanizes both sides to each other, planting the seeds for eventual reconciliation. It demonstrates that tragedy can sometimes unite former enemies through their common humanity.

events.title: Luffy Vows to Ring the Golden Bell
events.description: Despite being battered from his ongoing battle with Enel, Luffy declares with fierce determination that he will ring the golden bell before Enel can take it away. This declaration shows Luffy's commitment to fulfilling his promise and honoring the legacy of both Noland and Kalgara.
events.significance: This moment crystallizes Luffy's motivation for the final phase of the battle. It's not just about defeating Enel anymore - it's about preserving history, honoring promises made 400 years ago, and proving to Cricket that his ancestor Noland wasn't a liar. This elevates the fight from a simple battle to a mission with deep historical and emotional significance.

quotes.text: I'm going to ring that bell!
quotes.speaker: Monkey D. Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy's declaration at the end of the episode

events.title: Gomu Gomu no Yo-Yo
events.description: Luffy debuts the Gomu Gomu no Yo-Yo technique, using the golden ball attached to his arm to stretch himself far back and then snap forward with tremendous force, propelling himself through the air. This anime-original technique showcases Luffy's creative adaptation to fighting with the cumbersome gold ball.
events.significance: This technique demonstrates Luffy's remarkable ability to turn disadvantages into strengths. What Enel intended as a handicap - the massive gold ball - becomes a tool for Luffy's mobility and offense. It foreshadows how Luffy will ultimately use the gold ball as the key to his victory.

quotes.speaker: Monkey D. Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy uses his new technique to propel himself

events.title: Enel Plans Total Annihilation of Skypiea
events.description: After destroying Angel Island, Enel reveals his intention to create an even larger Raigo to obliterate all of Skypiea once he obtains the Golden Bell. His plan is to destroy everything and everyone, leaving nothing but the Fairy Vearth (the moon) as his destination.
events.significance: This escalates the stakes from protecting Angel Island to saving all of Skypiea. Enel's nihilistic plan to destroy everything establishes him as an existential threat. It also emphasizes the urgency of Luffy's mission - failure means the annihilation of everyone in the sky.

quotes.text: Once I have the Golden Bell, I'll create an even larger Raigo and destroy all of Skypiea!
quotes.speaker: Enel
quotes.context: Enel declares his intention to destroy everything

quotes.text: I'm going to ring that bell!
quotes.speaker: Monkey D. Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy's determination to ring the golden bell

quotes.text: The Golden Bell sits atop Giant Jack.
quotes.speaker: Nico Robin
quotes.context: Robin reveals the location to Wyper

quotes.text: Witness the true power of god! Raigo!
quotes.speaker: Enel

themes.theme: The Cost of War and Violence
themes.description: The episode powerfully depicts the devastating consequences of violence and conflict through the complete destruction of Angel Island. The imagery of mass destruction and the survivors' grief emphasizes that war and violence leave lasting scars on innocent people.
themes.symbolism: The Raigo attack's resemblance to an atomic bomb serves as a powerful anti-war symbol, particularly resonant in Japanese culture. The crater left in the clouds represents the permanent void left by senseless destruction.
culturalReferences: The atomic bomb imagery evokes Japan's historical trauma from Hiroshima and Nagasaki

themes.description: The episode shows how shared tragedy can begin to heal old wounds, as Skypieans and Shandians - enemies for 400 years - find common ground in their mutual grief over lost loved ones.
themes.symbolism: The tears shed by both peoples represent the universal nature of human suffering and loss, transcending cultural and historical divides.

themes.description: Luffy's determination to ring the bell represents the importance of preserving historical truth and honoring the past, even in the face of overwhelming adversity. The bell symbolizes both Noland's vindication and the Shandians' ancestral heritage.
themes.symbolism: The Golden Bell represents truth that has been buried but cannot be destroyed. Luffy's vow to ring it symbolizes the inevitable resurfacing of historical truth.

themes.description: Enel's casual destruction of Angel Island exemplifies the dangers of absolute power and those who claim divine authority to justify atrocities. His god complex allows him to commit mass murder without remorse.
themes.symbolism: Enel as a self-proclaimed god represents the destructive nature of unchecked power and religious extremism.

characterSpotlights.development: Despite being exhausted and battered, Luffy shows unwavering determination to fulfill his promise. His declaration to ring the bell demonstrates his growth in understanding the weight of history and promises.
keyActions: Uses Gomu Gomu no Yo-Yo to maneuver with the gold ball
Witnesses the destruction of Angel Island
Declares his determination to ring the golden bell
quotes: I'm going to ring that bell!

characterSpotlights.development: Enel reaches the peak of his villainy by committing mass murder without hesitation. His calm demeanor while destroying Angel Island emphasizes his complete lack of empathy and his twisted god complex.
keyActions: Unleashes Raigo technique for the first time
Reveals plan to annihilate all of Skypiea
quotes: Witness the true power of god! Raigo!

characterSpotlights.development: Robin serves as the bridge between past and present, using her archaeological knowledge and Noland's log book to reveal crucial information about the Golden Bell's location.
keyActions: Reveals the Golden Bell's location to Wyper
References Noland's log book as evidence
quotes: The Golden Bell sits atop Giant Jack.

characterSpotlights.development: Wyper struggles with whether to believe Robin's claim about the bell's location after 400 years of fruitless searching. His initial skepticism shows the weight of generational disappointment.
keyActions: Questions Robin's claims about the Golden Bell
Processes the revelation about Giant Jack
Witnesses the destruction alongside other survivors

mangaDifferences.difference: The Gomu Gomu no Yo-Yo technique is anime-original and does not appear in the manga. The anime extended Luffy's fight scenes with additional techniques.
The visual depiction of the Raigo's destruction with mushroom cloud imagery is more explicit in the anime than in the manga, emphasizing the atomic bomb parallel.

trivia.fact: The Raigo attack's visual presentation deliberately evokes atomic bomb imagery, creating a powerful anti-war message particularly resonant with Japanese audiences who experienced Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

sources.title: Never Watched One Piece - Episode 190 Review

trivia.fact: Episode 190 aired on April 25, 2004 in Japan, but episodes 168-195 were skipped during the U.S. television broadcast and only released on DVD by Funimation on December 30, 2008.
This episode achieved a 9.8% TV rating in Japan, ranking 7th among One Piece episodes for viewership at the time.
The episode's eyecatcher features Sanji and Luffy, highlighting the Straw Hat crew members who would play crucial roles in the arc's resolution.
Toshiyuki Morikawa, who voices Enel, is also known for voicing other iconic villainous characters including Sephiroth in Final Fantasy and Yoshikage Kira in JoJo's Bizarre Adventure.
